subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: We tried the error string as the third parameter (generally speaking I put optional parameters at the end of the parameter list), but we had a compile error,
messageBody:
We tried the error string as the third parameter (generally speaking I put
optional parameters at the end of the parameter list), but we had a compile
error, the details of which I don't remember. That's how we ended up with
the error message as the first parameter.

As far as the order of parameters in assertEquals(expected, actual), as I
recall this came from my observation that the expected value is often quite
short, simple, and easy to read while the actual value can come from a
complex expression. I find this:
assertEquals(5, result.ofComplexCalculation(withParameters,
andMoreParameters));
easier to read than the reverse. However, tests won't break if you switch
the order of the parameters, you'll just get confusing error messages if the
assertion fails.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

>
> Agreed. And since we're nitpicking, I also don't think the
> failure string
> should be the first parameter. When I look at an assertion, I am more
> interested in what is being tested than what will be
> displayed in the case
> of a failure.
>
> Spot the test:
>
> assertEquals("The sky doesn't seem to be blue, please take a
> look outside
> and confirm", sky.color(), "blue");
>
> assertEquals(sky.color(), "blue",
> "The sky doesn't seem to be blue, please take a look outside and
> confirm");
